stem: A 55-year-old client with severe sepsis develops progressive hypoxemia that is unresponsive to increasing oxygen concentrations. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral 'white-out' infiltrates. Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Position the client in a prone position
Perform a thoracentesis at the bedside
Maintain a high-volume fluid resuscitation strategy
Prepare for sedation and mechanical ventilation with PEEP

parameters.text: Peak airway pressures and lung compliance

rationale.correct: ARDS involves refractory hypoxemia and leaky pulmonary capillaries. Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is critical to keep alveoli open. Prone positioning helps improve V/Q matching. PaO2/FiO2 ratio is the diagnostic and monitoring gold standard for ARDS severity.
rationale.incorrect: ARDS management usually benefits from a conservative ('dry') fluid strategy to prevent worse edema. Thoracentesis is for effusion, not the parenchymal edema of ARDS.
clinicalPearls: Peep improves oxygenation but can cause barotrauma and decreased cardiac output.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the SpO2 doesn't go up even when you give more Oxygen, think ARDS.

mnemonic.title: ARDS
mnemonic.expansion:
A = Acute
R = Respiratory
D = Distress
S = Syndrome

Key Actions: Prepare for sedation and mechanical ventilation with PEEP; Position the client in a prone position
Key Monitoring: PaO2/FiO2 ratio; Peak airway pressures and lung compliance

reviewUnits.heading: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: ARDS involves refractory hypoxemia and leaky pulmonary capillaries. Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is critical to keep alveoli open. Prone positioning helps improve V/Q matching. PaO2/FiO2 ratio is the diagnostic and monitoring gold standard for ARDS severity. Peep improves oxygenation but can cause barotrauma and decreased cardiac output.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Prepare for sedation and mechanical ventilation with PEEP; Position the client in a prone position. Monitor: PaO2/FiO2 ratio; Peak airway pressures and lung compliance. ARDS management usually benefits from a conservative ('dry') fluid strategy to prevent worse edema. Thoracentesis is for effusion, not the parenchymal edema of ARDS.
